thread.title: Government accused of trying to 'fool' residents over £1.3bn funding promise

author: nechronicle
title: Government accused of trying to 'fool' residents over £1.3bn funding promise
text:
News Government accused of trying to 'fool' residents over £1.3bn funding promise Newcastle City Council leader Nick Forbes has accused the Government of attempting to 'fool residents into thinking the bad times are over' Share Newcastle City Council leader Nick Forbes has handed in a petition to number 10 Downing Street (Image: PA/NCJ Media) Get daily
Government pledges to increase funding to local councils are simply an attempt to “fool residents into thinking the bad times are over”, according to Newcastle’s Labour leader.
It was announced on Thursday that local authorities across England will get a share of an extra £1.3bn in 2019/20.
But Newcastle City Council leader Nick Forbes has accused the Government of ‘repackaging’ previously-announced funding pots.
Civic centre bosses in Newcastle have been forced to slash more than £250m from their budget since 2010, and must find another £60m worth of cuts in the next three years.
Coun Forbes said: “What we’ve seen today is that austerity is far from over. Limited one-off funds announced in the budget were repackaged in attempt to fool residents into thinking the bad times are over. Read More What happens now with Brexit? Theresa May's next move after no confidence vote
“But the reality is there was no new money for libraries, no new money for street cleaning and no long term funding assurances for care services already at breaking point.
“ Newcastle alone has to save £60m over the next three years, but when I have warned ministers about the impact of these cuts, their response has just been to pass the bill to local taxpayers.”
The Local Government Association says that all councils still face an overall funding gap of £3.2bn in 2019/20. Read More Taxi drivers call for clean air toll plans for Newcastle roads to be scrapped
The provisional Local Government finance settlement announced on Thursday, a week later than expected due to Brexit debates, reiterates that the Autumn Budget committed £650m more for social care for 2019 to 2020.
It also confirmed that the North of Tyne Combined Authority area - Newcastle, Northumberland, and Gateshead - will become a pilot area for a project allowing local councils to retain 75% of business rates.
Communities Secretary James Brokenshire MP said: “I’m delivering a settlement which paves the way for a fairer, more self-sufficient and resilient future for Local Government and a brighter future for the people and places they serve. Read More
